content: Crime reports up in South Korea after curfew eased SEOUL — Six months after the weekend curfew in South Korea was shortened, a rise in sexual assaults and other crimes committed by U.S. troops could push U.S. Forces Korea to lengthen it. In a "Sharp Point" message posted Wednesday on the command’s Web site, USFK commander Gen. Walter Sharp said incidents of sexual assaults, aggravated assaults, assaults and disorderly conduct have increased since the curfew was shortened to two hours beginning Aug. 15. Under the current curfew, troops are required to be indoors from 3 to 5 a.m. on Saturdays, Sundays and U.S.-observed holidays. The previous weekend curfew was 1 to 5 a.m. Sharp’s assessment was based on a six-month review of the policy’s impact on troop behavior. "This is unacceptable and we must act now to correct this trend," he said. >http://www.stripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=61768 Good going troops, keep up the good work to make such a good impression.

title: Crime reports up in South Korea after curfew eased

content: Is this just the nature of the beast or is it a direct reflection on lowering of the standards of enlistment?
reply: Is this just the nature of the beast or is it a direct reflection on lowering of the standards of enlistment?
title: Crime reports up in South Korea after curfew eased

content: Indiscipline prompts Korea stand-down order Monday Apr 6, 2009 Noting a steady increase in serious acts of indiscipline since the easing of weekend curfew restrictions six months ago, the senior commander of U.S. Forces Korea has ordered an all-ranks and services training stand down April 25 to focus on military standards. In an April 1 notice to all U.S. forces in South Korea, Gen. Walter L. Sharp ordered the four-hour Saturday muster because “the number of acts of sexual assaults, aggravated assaults, assaults and disorderly conduct have increased … since last August when the relaxed curfew was put into effect.” The Army Times >http://www.armytimes.com/news/2009/04/army_standdown_040609w/

content: I was stationed in Pusan in '02-'03. Best assignment in Korea in my opinion. The MP's only patrolled 2 places in the whole city, and not every weekend. Around 500 Army, and 30+ Air Force. Most of the bar girls were Russian. No problems with crime either. Too bad they closed the base. I would never want to be stationed there again now. With all the smaller base closures, there's too much young testosterone crammed into the bigger bases.
